byline.contributor: Austin Frakt is a health economist with several governmental and academic affiliations. He blogs at The Incidental Economist, and you can follow him on Twitter at @afrakt.

abstract: The Upshot; financial incentives are important in hospital admission and discharge decisions for patients; average hospital stay in United States is around 4.5 days, compared with 7.3 days in 1980; shift appears to be result of Medicare's decision to only pay predetermined rate linked to individual patient's diagnosis rather than what hospitals claimed their costs were.

headline.print_headline: Money Influences the Length of Hospital Stays
headline.main: The Hidden Financial Incentives Behind Your Shorter Hospital Stay

snippet: Changes to how hospitals are paid can affect both admission and discharge decisions.
lead_paragraph: Changes to how hospitals are paid can affect both admission and discharge decisions.
